author: Rollmottle
content:
I went to art school and its entire foundation was built on the process of critique. You learn to tear the work down as a means to burnish and gird the ideas. I learned very early to not get so emotionally attached to my work because there was very often ample headroom to keep pushing the ideas further and ultimately get the work to a more realized and better state. It has been my experience having worked in a creative field beyond music and painting for over 25 years, that the people who are most successful, welcome and embrace critique and don’t get sent down an unproductive path when their ideas are challenged. It can be very difficult to hear that what you thought was a good idea, might not actually be. As creative folk, we have to find ways to separate how our sensitive nature absolutely helps us and at times, gets in our way. We needn’t be so precious about things, especially if holding on holds us back. 

I’ve found being very direct without beating around the bush is a way more effective means of communicating and leads to better places more quickly. It is a skill to learn to operate alongside people who won ’t sugarcoat their feedback in pursuit of better outcomes. The earlier one can learn how to thrive within that framework, I think the better off you will be.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So there’s an old saying: if you wanna really know something, you gotta learn it, you gotta do it, then you gotta teach it. 

My friend who mentioned wanting to learn how to mix yesterday was amazed at how fast I was able to make his track sound big and loud and open all at the same time. “My mix sounded so small and congested. Yours sounds huge.”


Basically what I did, besides level & panning, was carve out a bunch of like 400 in all harmonic elements. All the tracks sounded good, but the density was all bunched up down in that range. 

As I was explaining it to him, I had a moment of clarity about headroom. Doesn’t matter if all frequencies are present for a big and tall mix, if all the headroom is getting eaten up by everything hitting the same frequencies, the collective volume of that is gonna make everything else feel quieter. 

I usually think of headroom in regard to low end and transients, but it’s true for every part of a mix.

author: Rollmottle
content:
1. Take everything but your mixer out of your summing signal path. Set its gain to where it will be when you're summing.
2. Insert a tone generator in your DAW and route it out to your summing rig.
3. Insert a trim plugin that can adjust L&R separately on the summing return in your DAW. Insert a meter like Izotope Insight before it if your trim plugin doesn't have good metering.
4. Play a 1khz sine wave from your tone generator.
5. See what your return is showing you.
6. Offset the level accordingly. 
7. Profit.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
As a mastering engineer, I’ve kept my monitoring level consistent for the past ten years—at a relatively low volume. This isn’t a rule, just my approach, and I do it because I know exactly how a finished track should sound in my room at that level.

Every system has a sweet spot, and if you can identify that in your setup, you’ll get more consistent results. This ties into factors like speaker and amp combinations, how your speakers push air—especially in the low end—and how they perform at different volumes.

Many speakers don’t reproduce low frequencies accurately when played too softly. On the flip side, when pushed too hard, speakers often cap the low end, meaning the bass stops getting louder while the mids and highs continue increasing. This is common in everyday listening setups—people crank their systems beyond their limits, causing an imbalance where the top end dominates.

This is one reason why working with a mastering engineer with a well-calibrated setup can be beneficial. But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to do things—some engineers work in less-than-ideal setups and still get great results. It all comes down to what works for you and gets you the sound you like.

One thing that’s important to remember which i amsure you already know.... your ears perceive frequencies differently at different volumes—this is a well-documented, non-linear effect. The way we hear balance changes with loudness, which is why understanding how your room and speakers respond at your chosen listening level can make a huge difference in achieving consistent, reliable masters. If you crank it... "memorize" in your ears how it should sound cranked. Then when you drop down to another level.."memorize" how it sounds there. You should then find a few spots you can use.

author: cian riordan
content: This “pre-gain staging your template” thing sounds like you’d be backing yourself into even more trouble. Templates are meant to be flexible and you’ll always need to make adjustments to make things work for the track. Let’s say you calibrate your drum bus for 1 dB of gain reduction — what does that do to account for the overall mean volume of those drums? The frequency density? It’s such a weird esoteric metric to try and quantify the signal you’re sending through it. Best thing you could do is setup your template to be able to do broad stroke gain adjustments within, very quickly, to get your chains hitting the way you like.

author: Maxim
content:
I think that might be a limiting factor on top of the artists' abilities (Pop Smoke already sounded dope before his setup got professional https://youtu.be/317TP4JOSSE). I've recorded not-so-great rappers through nice chains and mixing wasn't the answer to save a (lacking) source. It never gave you *that* feeling. But even if you are recording great rappers cheaper mics tend to lack body and rarely have "boostable" or pleasant top end as you said. So it's a bit complicated before you even get to "mixing". Felt that was important to mention so you're not too hard on yourself.

But assuming that the limiting factor really is just mixing there's a bunch of options. First things first: is your monitoring and listening environment decent? Or are you on headphones? This could make placing vocals even harder for you. 

Then do you have a process that starts with vocal cleanup to get rid of or reduce unappealing harshness or performance issues? Despite being simple, people tend to skip basic tools like clip-gain to even out a performance. This should usually also give you some leeway for strategic boosts. Maybe instead of EQ look at harmonics. Fresh Air by Slate is free. Gem Dopamine is nice. Spectre is great. All of these should give you that "sizzle" you might be missing.

Then to get the presence and even out the performance you could try some parallel compression with something like an 1176. Also, try out Multiband Compression with the Mcdsp 404 or C6 or whatever you have to control the performance throughout the song once you've got a vocal sound you like.

I also find mixing the 808 & drums together with the vocal the most useful when it comes to gain staging and getting the song to feel right.

Obviously, there's more that could be said but I find processes more helpful than tools. It's art at the end of the day. Attached what Serban's assistant sees as their/his "mixing process". Mix more and experiment with what you have. Get feedback from the artists.

Id assume it be a slightly slow attack in a context of a limiter instead of a compressor (longer attack time) 
You can if the limiter has a look ahead function built in. Taken from the fabfilter Pro L manual 
“Lookahead
The Lookahead knob sets the look-ahead time for the initial 'transient' stage. This allows the limiter to examine the incoming audio in advance and predict the amount of gain reduction needed to meet the requested output level. If the look-ahead time is very short, the limiter doesn't have much time to move to the desired level: this will generally have the effect of preserving transients better and increasing the apparent loudness, but at the expense of possible distortion. Longer look-ahead times are safer, but less loud, and transients might appear to get lost in the mix a little more.”

20% is a metric ton of saturation imo. 

Soft Clip Classic

This is the default algorithm, and it’s the same one, which was used in the previous version.

Soft Clip Pro

This new algorithm has a slightly different characteristic. It compresses an adjustable dynamic range by half. A line in the function plot shows from which level the saturation begins. The dynamic integrity below this threshold stays intact.

25% - compresses the last 6 dB into 3 dB, and adds 3 dB
50% - compresses the last 12 dB into 6 dB, and adds 6 dB
75% - compresses the last 18 dB into 9 dB, and adds 9 dB

So my first big boy professional mix for another artist other than myself, I used busses like a summing mixer. I slapped defaulted Gem Dopamine on each bus for “analogue vibe” and went about mixing. 

The mix turned out dope, but not because the analogue simulacrum. The busses forced me to pay attention to gain-staging and overall headroom. But I didn’t learn that until later. Now I don’t try to simulate analogue summing, and I use just the Master Buss to figure out gain staging, but the proper principals I learned doing an “improper” thing have stuck with me. 

All that’s to say- mix in mono, reference, use busses… but pay attention to what’s working and why. Chances are you can learn more and faster if you’re not intent on proving only a certain outcome.

The loudness war is by no means over and never will be lol. Fucking myth. To get mega-loudness, you definitely need to stack limiters. Couple strategies to get you there:
- Make sure your De-essing is dialed in. That should soften some of the peaks that will end up gnarly once munched through multiple limiter stages.
- I've found I can get there much easier by driving a lot of density in the analog stage.
- Parallel processing can give you extra density and perceived loudness
- De-ess again if you have to
- One chain I've found great success in is: StandardClip after the analog stage into the Weiss Maximizer then into the ProL2. That has gotten me very clean and very fucking loud masters, but that is post an analog stage that is built for high headroom to drive serious level in the analog domain.

the case is the same digital or analog. it's a helpful tool to keep your gain staging in check. the key is what you calibrate the meter to and where you place it. 

it seems particularly useful on making sure you're hitting known processing chain inputs in their sweet spot. put the meter before any bus processing chain and calibrate the meter to its sweet spot. now you know quickly when you're hitting (or not hitting) the spot where you know it can do the thing in the way you expect it to do the thing. the other really useful one is post bus processing. set the meter on a bus output calibrated to a target level, now you know how gain decisions within the bus are or are not getting you where you want to be. for those working in templates and mixing into known bus processing chains, it seems like it would take a lot of the guess work out of gain staging decisions. it's a very broad stroke tool, but helps me very quickly make decisions on what level something needs to be juiced up or down to. just takes a little upfront work.

author: rse
content: A hard clipper will behave differently than the digital clipping that occurs when you clip your converters or when you export a signal that exceeds 0db at a bit depth of 24bits. Your daw works internally at 32bits floating point, which means that your individual faders will have a lot of headroom above 0 db, so you can go pretty much as high as you want with them, as long as you turn the signal down in a later stage before it hits the final output. Otherwise you will be clipping your converters like you said. This clipping will be different for every converter, and it's why mastering guys buy converters that are worth more than your car, just so they can get a certain flavour when clipping their a/d (although I'm pretty sure most have stopped doing this, because it often just sounds like shit lmao). Clipping your signal with a plugin will introduce different distortion/saturation/artifacts. It will even be different between different plugins and between different algorithms inside of those plugins (if you are able to select those)  (some clipping plugins actually use the exact same algorithms, so those won't have any differences ofc. EDIT: the only differences here would be in the oversampling functionality etc. of the plugins used, not in the actual clipping algorithm. There actually aren't a lot of hard clipping algorithms out there, so most differences between plugins will be in the way the anti-aliasing filters work)

author: Maxim
content:
“The Inflator is not the same as the Enhance feature in the Oxford Limiter, although the effects might be considered similar. In simple terms, the Inflator is a special kind of distortion generator which has no dynamic activity over time. It's a static process. It gives the impression of loudness by providing the harmonic cues we associate with loud and stressed sounds, increasing the harmonic density of the material in a way that is sympathetic to the ear.

The Oxford Limiter's Enhance function is a special kind of 'dynamic' process that does not add distortion to steady state signals. It works over time, programme history, peak and average levels and left/right stereo differences to limit the signal and squash peak events, while providing the listener with the impression that the peaks are still there. It can sympathetically remove peak events so that you can provide more transparent limiting, or make the programme even louder without causing sample value overs.”

author: Maxim
content:
And from the manual:
“The enhance process improves the perceived loudness and presence of the programme material by modifying the dynamic and harmonic content of the signal. Since the method used is different from the Pre-Processing section, it can further enhance the perceived volume of a previously processed signal, while suppressing all signal overloads. As the limiting action does not involve conventional sample value clipping, harsh distortions are avoided, and programme detail and dynamic information is largely retained.

Also, since the plug-in has internal headroom, transient levels greater than notional maximum modulation can pass from the Limiter section into the enhancement stage. This means that percussive overshoots, that would normally be lost in a conventional limiter (or would give rise to overloads), may be included within the sonic results of the plug-in, producing both richer dynamic sonic detail and a useful reduction in the perceived artefacts of the limiting process, all without giving rise to any sample value overload.

This property enables slower attack times to be used in the Pre-Process section, without creating output overloads, which would otherwise result in a need to reduce output levels.”

Some discoveries I made about compression for the past year is that the purposes you mentioned relate very much to the being able to pack more in the limited digital space (loudness) and bringing things forward and back.

author: JustinLeu
content:
But honestly I feel like the LUFS level matching is a pretty nuanced topic. 

On one hand…
everyone only gets to work within 0db full scale, which is where “the loudness war” originated. The question becomes the trade off in loudness vs the mix suffering (which is a bit subjective)

On the other hand…
Most services default to roughly level matching songs to their target LUFS which is where the extremely misguided “loudness penalty” idea came from. BUT when services level matching different songs, sometimes you can get away with more dynamic range.

I typically do not worry at all about what number I’m hitting once a mix is feeling great. I may push it a bit louder to see what happens, and also check how it feels a bit more dynamic.

author: Rob Domos
content:
No one should care about this, but theoretically it’s possible for you to end up with a different result. 

Example: Let’s say you dither at 24, you now have 22 bits of signal leaving you with changes at -132. Now let’s say they exported the song rather quietly to leave headroom for the ME and the whole record needs to be gained up 6db. And let’s say that the song is really dynamic and verse 1 need to be brought up another 6db for consistent level, and then we’re limiting 3db on top of that. We’re now at the point where changes to the signal are at -117, which is getting into the territory of the difference between converters.  

So if you feel like you can hear the difference between an Apollo and a topping D/A, there will be occasional times where the same would hold true of a 24 bit file where nothing clipped

author: Ed Sokolowski
content:
SNR thing is somewhat overblown IMO, especially these days. Background noise is going to be quite a lot louder than A/D noise unless you have a really old interface, or really quiet signal. Even in ideal conditions, DI’s are unlikely to have more than 100dB in dynamic range.

There’s also a thing where a lot of amp sims need REALLY high (like un-intuitively loud) signals. To reach “unity” gain in Softube’s Marshalls or a lot of Amplitube amps, you essentially need to be just below clipping and then boost another 10-15dB or so

author: Ed Sokolowski
content: Yeah. The specs that most manufacturers give us with gain at minimum (for maximum headroom). These days they’ll basically always set the headroom for instrument inputs at minimum gain to be around 11-13dBu, which is around 3V. And that’s about as much as you’ll get out of humbuckers or a 9V pedal. High output pickups might JUST clip at 13dBu so it’ll likely be more than loud enough even without adding any extra gain.

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus.
